head.title: G.O.P. Agrees to Act On Speaker Fee Ban

hedline.hl1: G.O.P. Agrees to Act On Speaker Fee Ban

abstract.p: Senate Republicans agree to request from Chief Justice William H Rehnquist to introduce legislation repealing 11-year ban on speaking fees for members of federal judiciary; Rehnquist seeks to relieve financial pressures on judges (S)

block.p: Senate Republicans have agreed to a request from Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to introduce legislation repealing an 11-year ban on speaking fees for members of the federal judiciary, officials said today.

In a letter to Senator Mitch McConnell this summer, Mr. Rehnquist asked for an end to the ban as a way to relieve financial pressures on judges, said David A. Sellers, a spokesman for the Administrative Office of the Courts.

Senate Republicans have agreed to a request from Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist to introduce legislation repealing an 11-year ban on speaking fees for members of the federal judiciary, officials said today.

In a letter to Senator Mitch McConnell this summer, Mr. Rehnquist asked for an end to the ban as a way to relieve financial pressures on judges, said David A. Sellers, a spokesman for the Administrative Office of the Courts.

Mr. McConnell and other senators obliged, including a repeal of the ban in the spending bill for the Commerce, State and Justice Departments, which was approved in committee on July 18. The bill is now before the full Senate.

The 1989 Ethics Reform Act barred lawmakers, judges and administration officials from receiving honorariums. The efforts by Justice Rehnquist to lift the ban were first reported in today's Washington Post.
